name: trillium-stamineum
wildlife-value: Attracts flies and beetles for pollination
edibility: EDIBLE PARTS: Young, unfolding leaves HARVEST TIME: Only collect leaves from areas you know have NOT been treated with pesticides. SAFE HANDLING PROCEDURES: Wash leaves in warm water to remove dirt and debris. Do not use dish detergent or any type of sanitizer. These products can leave a residue. Cook in boiling, salted water for ten minutes and serve like greens. SOURCE: Crowhurst, A. 1972. The Weed Cookbook. Lancer Books, Inc. New York, 190 pp.
light: Dappled Sunlight (Shade through upper canopy all day)
Deep shade (Less than 2 hours to no direct sunlight)
Partial Shade (Direct sunlight only part of the day, 2-6 hours)
fruit-description: 6-parted berry-like capsule with seeds that are dispersed by ants in th summer.
flower-description: The petals are a very deep maroon to blackish-red, and purple-streaked. Waxy recurved petals are horizontal and twisted. The large stamens are dark purple. The carrion-scented flower attracts flies and beetles for pollination. Blooms April to May
leaf-description: A whorl of 3 mottled ovate to ovate-lanceolate green sessile bracts are 2.5 to 3 inches long and 1.3-2 inches wide
stem-description: Smooth round green to purple stem
poison-toxic-principle: Toxicity unknown, but caution because of its relationship with known toxic plants.
uses: Trilliums have been used in herbal medicine
